response.answer_text: I have written a book. I’ve written a few, but this is the one I’ve been working on for most of 2018. It was edited and published on Kindle just a day or two before it would have been ineligible for entering in The Thurber Prize for American Humor contest in 2019. Books that are entered in The Thurber contest have to be published traditionally, or in an “e” version, between January 01 and December 31st of the previous year. THURBER PRIZE FOR AMERICAN HUMOR SUBMISSIONS Awarded annually, the Thurber Prize for American Humor is the highest recognition of the art of humor writing in the United States. A panel of national judges selects three finalists from seven or eight semi-finalists. The winner receives $5,000 and a commemorative plaque. Previously held in New York City, the Thurber Prize returned to its hometown roots—Columbus, Ohio—in 2018. The three finalists are required to attend the awards ceremony in Columbus, Ohio. Guests are entertained during a spectacular evening of humor culminating with the announcement of the winner of the Thurber Prize for American Humor. A commemorative plaque! Shoot, if I don’t win, I’ll just order one up from Office Depot and hang it next to my Pulitzer. The contest was what motivated me to start and then finish the book. When I have a target and a deadline, I work harder. I don’t mind if I lose, well, not much, but the fact that I finished something for a specific purpose is satisfying. Skewing everyone’s favorite proverbs was also part of the fun. And going to a “spectacular evening of humor” would be the bomb. Last year, the books submitted to the Thurber contest were from authors like Dave Barry, Paula Poundstone, and in previous years, Jon Stewart and David Sedaris. But they didn’t win the 2018 prize; that was won by an unknown. At least she is to me. If the judges like to see submissions from bottom writers, there is hope for me yet. I can’t do a free promotion as I’d like without enrolling the book in KDP Select, which I don’t want to do. So, I’ve priced it very reasonably at $3.99. If you do buy my book and read it and feel so inclined, please leave me a review. Amazon won’t let people leave reviews who haven’t spent $50 on the site, just to give you a head’s up.  https://www.amazon.com/dp/B082KRKLDW Thurber House — ABOUT JAMES THURBER — Literary Center and James Thurber Museum And since this one was published, I wrote a fourth:  https://www.amazon.com/dp/B07X3QSB6L Dang, these images come out big.

I haven't, but I'm working on one. It all started because I was tired of books which have a tonne of romance. (I'm not a great fan of romance.) I wanted something with interesting characters that weren't romantically involved. That had some internal conflict, in a little mysterious world. I always had some rough, random scenes playing in my mind. (Maladaptive fantasy…) One day, I was feeling angry, and to diffuse the feeling, I wrote a scene. A random scene, where a girl faced a creature she had never seen before. I ended up writing a full action scene. By the end, I had already thought of what the creature would be like, where it came from, and what the secret behind it all was. I’d come up with my idea. Then I thought of who the girl would be. I wanted to give her some of my characteristics, but also other very different qualities that set her apart as a character of her own. She'd be the fantasy character I always wanted to read about. (An xNTx type of a character). I’ve two other different main characters planned, too. It's going to be epic fantasy. I've made some notes about what kind of a planet it is, where my story is set. I have researched a little bit of the science behind it, because since the world is different, the weather patterns, the life, all will be different. I need to have some logical, plausible reasoning for all that. (I have a thing for logic.) Besides, it only makes sense. Ever wondered what kind of plants would grow on a world like that? What the economy runs on? Those things matter to me. That's the world building I'm working on. So yeah, I’ve created a mental outline of the plot, and actually have an idea how my story is going to end. Thinking is easy though. I'm facing trouble with filling it up. It's hard to put the scenes to paper (type it, actually). And it's hard to write believable, natural dialogue, while simultaneously developing the world in the story. It shouldn't seem pretentious, and come off smoothly. But to answer your question, I've written a few scenes and started working on who my characters are, and where they're going to end.

Well, it’s funny you should ask that, no one, because it just so happens that I have written a book. My profile now has actual links to actual pages on actual Amazon with my actual book available for actual purchase. (Yes; actually.)  I’ve made a few posts about it on my Quora space and referred to it in one or two answers, but self-publicity is always something I’m a bit reluctant with. Plus, none of those posts actually got many views compared to my usual ones, so I’m hoping this will inform some people who are actually interested but haven’t seen those posts. It’s the culmination of almost two years of work (on-and-off, but mostly on since this coronavirus business), starting when I wrote some silly Quora answers about hypothetical animal combat, and they actually went down quite well. Several people have mentioned that I haven’t been writing those kinds of answers as much recently, and a big part of that is that I was writing new material for the book and wanted to keep it a surprise/not post on Quora. Some of the match-ups were inspired by Quora, but they’re a lot different in the book, having been reworded, extended and reformatted. About 2/3 of the battles are completely new. All contain ample alliteration, painful puns, and anthropomorphised animals questioning whether they’ve been anthropomorphised or not. There are new segments, and there may or may not be an interview with a coconut. It’s been a learning experience, and I won’t say I didn’t question why I was spending so much time on a fairly weird topic, but I put a lot of work into it and, in my humble opinion, it’s pretty funny and pretty informative. (You might start to hate me if you read the same jokes 15,000 times like I did, but it’s unlikely you’ll be that committed.) If you like my animal answers on Quora, I think you’ll enjoy it. It’s more of the same, but (imo) a higher standard, more detailed, and something I took way more seriously. If people are paying money, I feel accountable for making sure it’s worth it. I really tried to give it the structure and feel of a “real” book. I learned that you should not start writing a manuscript on Google docs. I learned that you should not write a manuscript on Word without formatting it properly. I learned that Kindle Create software—while mostly pretty handy—will sometimes attempt to bend you over and penetrate you from behind. Do not talk to me about pictures. (If there’s a next time, maybe I should just write a traditional novel with words. Sweet words, and no pictures to format and compress and resize.) At least I can say I am now an author, albeit a self-published one. Thanks to everyone who had nice things to say about my answers; thanks to everyone who suggested I compile them/reacted positively when I suggested it, and thanks to everyone who believed some silly myths about animals that I felt compelled to dispel. Thanks in advance to anyone who does buy a copy (or even reads it on Kindle unlimited). I really appreciate you guys giving me a platform to talk nonsense about animals. Now I need a lie down. And a drink. Edit — it hasn’t taken that many sales to make it there, but it’s reached the Number 1 “Hot New Release” in a couple of categories on the US site:  Thanks to those who have bought it, and I hope you enjoy it.

Yes. Two. :) Dissecting Antismokers' Brains and TobakkoNacht - The Antismoking Endgame DAB was published in 2003, and TN in 2013. As you can guess from the titles, they’re both in the same subject area, and if you click on the tabs on their sites you can find extensive excerpts for reading (particularly for TN under the front cover image’s “Book Selections” tabs). Both were difficult to write because of the amount of research needed for parts of them dealing with health and science, and the knowledge that even a single small error or inadvertent distortion in either could be blown up to discredit the entire book. Together they come to about 850 pages and 275,000 words with over a thousand citations and references. Heh, writing fiction is MUCH easier (TN actually does have 60 pages or so of fiction in the form of “bookend” opening and closing short stories.) Unfortunately, despite being a very devoted fiction reader of probably 10,000 or so novels in my life, I’ve never had any real talent for writing it. The two pieces in TobakkoNacht were politically inspired oddities that just sort of popped out unexpectedly, and my lack of skill in the area is shown by the fact that I worked out formats for both stories that allowed me to avoid any need for dialogue. Here’s the shorty closing bookend (650 words) from my Blog here on Quora if you like: Michael’s Breathers . (Breathers is particularly appropriate today, two years after I wrote and posted the rest of this answer: we are heading straight there now, courtesy of the COVID-19 virus.) I chose to self-publish because the subject matter for DAB was both very unique (heh, as opposed to only somewhat unique? :> ) and very sensitive politically. Giving it to the wrong publisher in 2003 could have resulted in it being bottled up for years — at a time period when it seemed quite important to get it into circulation quickly. Self-publishing also gave me ready access to relatively cheap copies that I could simply give to bar-owners and such who needed to read it but who would have been too sceptical to lay out money for it. Self-pubbing is NOT easy however… just in case you’re thinking of doing it. There’s a LOT of work involved to do it right, and a LOT of pitfalls along the way that can screw things up. Check and join the yahoo POD_Publishers group and read through the thousands of messages there for a lot of good background info. I’m sure there are other good sources as well, including several books and free resources by Aaron Shepard (See *Self Publishing* AARON SHEPARD'S PUBLISHING PAGE *POD Publishing with Lightning Source and CreateSpace, Ebook Publishing on Kindle, Online Book Marketing on Amazon, DIY Book Design* ) who has helped hundreds of aspiring self-publishers over the years through the aforementioned yahoo group! Soooo…. that’s about it for my “Have I written a book?” Dunno if there’ll be another anytime soon. As noted, it IS a lot of work. MJM, who’d write a book titled “How To Care For Your Cactus” except for the fact that mine died due to lack of care…

Yes, yes I have! I’ve written three books: How to be Ferociously Happy, a very easy to read, simple book of short essays aimed at shifting someone’s perspective towards being happier.  Amateur, a book of short stories.  A Spectacular Catastrophe and Other Things I Recommend, a book about how to survive adversity and suffer less.  I’m currently working on three more: One which I hope to publish this November (2017) which is another short story book. I am not certain about the title but I’m getting pretty close. One that I’m working on with Franklin Veaux for publication some time next year, which is a collection of things we wish someone had taught us in school. (If you have an idea for a title, bring it!) Another book that focuses only on career related essays: things I learned at work that made my life easier that I look forward to sharing. Maybe this one will be ready early 2019, maybe before that. What I’ve learned about writing books is that you just have to write them. Writing is more about discipline than anything else. Sit down in front of your computer and write.

I’ve published seven volumes of translations, mostly Old Norse sagas and similar texts, although one volume is translated Old English poetry. Possibly the best known is The Sagas of Ragnar Lodbrok, because the Vikings series is loosely based on it. (My translation came out in 2009. I don’t know whether anyone connected with the TV show ever read my work. Still, it’s been gratifying to watch the stories and characters that I grappled with turn into pop-culture icons.) The most recent saga anthology, quite a bit bigger than Ragnar’s book, was Six Sagas of Adventure; the characters are less famous than Ragnar & Co., but there’s plenty of fierce battles and wild escapes and beautiful monsters and savage princesses and all that good clean Viking fun. Aside from sagas, I’ve done a translation of a medieval medical manuscript (Norse Magical and Herbal Healing), and also a stab at Old English poetry (Say What I Am: A Book of Old English Riddles). All of these are available on Amazon. My latest assaults on literature are two small, slim, pocket-sized editions of Old Norse poems: Hávamál: A New Translation and Rígsthula: A New Translation. The humble yet proud polytheistic religious organization to which I belong, which you’ve probably never heard of, is donating copies of these to prison and military outreach—one donated copy for every purchased copy. So there’s that. These should be up on Amazon in a week or so. (Lyonel Perabo, I’ll be sending you copies once I get some extras.) There’s a much larger anthology of sagas that is currently in the final stages of preparation, coming out in October 2017 if all goes well, which I’m rather excited about.

The series begins with the book Maginaugh set in a time 9,000 years ago in a location now known as Macinac Island, Upper Michigan. It’s the story of an alien girl from a distant planet falling in love with a native girl of the Pewa (pre-Chippewa) tribe. One hundred and fifty years later, the alien protagonist meets a local wizard known as Vainamoinen who transforms her and her family and friends into Elves. The protagonist meets a local Elven girl who lives in the secret underground Elven city of Maahilund. There is an attraction based on the protagonist’s feeling that this Elven girl is her former lover reincarnated. It’s unrequited however and they remain simply friends, although they share the love of a male Elf. Orcs and Demons attack Maahilund and our protagonist is given a magic flaming sword, capable of killing Demons, so that she can lead the Maahilund Elves into battle.  Amazon.com: The Elves of Arthannegh (The Fair and Fey Book 3) eBook: J. Ellyne: Kindle Store In the third book, The Elves of Arthannegh, the protagonist is reincarnated 8,000 years later as a Nymph of Pan in northern Britannia during the Dark Ages. Vainamoinen meets her there again but this time he is going by the name Merlin. She meets another Nymph and they fall in love, or lust — it’s hard to tell the difference when it comes to Nymphs. Merlin tells them of their past, that the protagonist is actually the alien girl reincarnated and the other Nymph is her old lover, reincarnated now as a Nymph. He tells her of her destiny to obtain her sword once more and help the local Elves and British combat Orcs, Demons, and Roman soldiers. They are sent to the King of the Elves of Arthannegh to get the sword from him and to have him transform them both back into Elves. They meet Uther Pendragon during a solstice celebration in a magical circle of standing stones and our protagonist fulfills the first part of her destiny by helping him battle the Romans to win independence for Britannia. In return he helps her fight the Demons and Orcs of Arthannegh.  The Elves of Avalon (The Fair and Fey Book 4) - Kindle edition by J. Ellyne. Literature & Fiction Kindle eBooks @ Amazon.com. In the fourth book, The Elves of Avalon, our protagonist and her lover have left our world to live in Avalon where Uther’s son and daughter, Arthur and Anna Pendragon, have been taken to keep them safe from the invasion of Anglo Saxons and the continual onslaught of Orcs and Demons. Arthur and his sister fall in love. The Elven protagonist gives him her sword because Merlin says he will need it in order to fight the Demons, Orcs and Anglo-Saxons overrunning Britannia. She and her Elven lover go back to our world where Arthur recruits a small band of knights with the help of Merlin. The book follows the well documented twelve battles for British victory over the Anglo-Saxons and adds the Elves getting Arthur’s help to battle the Orcs and Demons. This book has a happier ending than the first two but Anna, now going by the name Morganna Le Fey, has a son by Arthur whom they name Merdraud (aka Mordred). A fey outcome of this union is foretold by Merlin.  The first four books are currently for sale on Amazon, Smashwords, Barnes & Noble, Apple, Kobo, and all other web sales sites world wide. They all received excellent reviews. My fifth book, Two Worlds Changed, has been completely written and is in the final stages of editing. It will be for sale on Amazon later this month (March). The Elves have returned to Avalon while Arthur stayed in Britannia, growing bored during the reign of peace ensuing after his final victory over the Anglo -Saxons at Badon Hill. The Demons won’t leave our protagonist alone. They attack the Elves on Avalon in Otherworld. Meanwhile Arthur goes off on a continental battle campaign in our world. His is forever a warrior. While he’s away, his son, Merdraud, steals his wife, Guinevere, causing a civil war to erupt in Brittannia. Arthur has to return to regain his kingdom and thus fulfills his fey destiny to do battle with his own son. This is the final book of the Fair and Fey series and you must read it to find out how everything turns out.

Amazon.com: Normandy: A Father's Ship and a Son's Curiosity (9780692086919): Cary, David: Books  Yes, I have written a book. It is available on Amazon now. This book began out of a request I received from my father in law, who was at Omaha Beach, to find out what happened to his ship. I wound up speaking with crew members and their families to get the personal sense. This book is all based on researched fact. The more I researched, the more I realized that if I did not write this book, the story of his ship and its crew would be lost forever. I felt a responsibility. Here are my observations: My background was Vietnam Era infantry. I know jungle warfare. The difference between my experience and that of a US Navy World War II sailor is so great, we might as well have been in different universes. We are now as far removed from them, as they were from the American Civil War.The United States, even though it started with a very small military, had one of the most sophisticated supply chain and economic systems in the world. Its economy was based on mass producing to fickle consumers. This meant it could turn on a dime and produce weapons over night, and it did. The US basically supplied all the allies.In two years, the US went from a very small military, particularly as it relates to ground forces, to 16.1 million people in uniform, superbly equipped and trained.No one doubted the Japanese would lose, not even the Japanese! They got caught up in an internal political dispute. How insane?Writing and research takes time and discipline.Stories about people are everything to have an interesting book.When one is steeped in the knowledge of a subject, it is easy to forget that not everyone knows what you know. An editor, an independent pair of eyes, is critical to produce a readable book.What is common knowledge about WWII for my generation, is not common knowledge for following generations. I wound up having to give a tight summary of WWII so readers could understand how the ship fit into the grand scheme of things.The book is now being incorporated into a movie. I am glad I did this but my next book will be about growing a successful technology company.

It is finally finished: A Deconstruction of the Left.  I wrote it for two reasons. 1. Because I have no choice. Social media doesn’t allow the free exchange of ideas anymore. 2. Because there is a lack of ideological material for my politics. There’s a lot of complaining but little in terms of alternatives. In 350 pages, 13 chapters, some 100 000 words and more than 600 footnotes I intended to do just that. The chapters are: Power structures. Here I make use of Michel Foucault. Initially I believed that Foucault said there are no truths and I wanted to show the fallacies of that (Jordan Peterson and Lindsey Graham and many others make that claim), but as I got into him, I could not find any evidence that this was Foucault’s intention. Instead, I made use of his ideas of power structures to show how the liberal left ideas are part of every aspect of society, including the justice system and the media.On truths. The scientific model as expressed by David Hume, but also how we can never be sure that the scientific model is correct (know as the problem of induction). I mention such thing as Plato’s noble myth.Academia. Various direct and indirect ways that academia is controlled by those in government.Schools. While schools are not directly controlled in its politics, it is being controlled by how the education is seeped in tolerance, human rights and anti-racism.Liberalism. A pretty heavy chapter where I look various claims of individualism, and related terms such as human rights. Many references to John Stuart Mill.What is the left-wing? - Another heavy chapter largely focused on Social Democracy in Sweden and its connection to socialism.A deconstruction of left-wing terminology. Including such phrases as what equality refers to, and who “the people” refers to. Inspired by Derrida, of course (another one of them postmodernists that Peterson and others despise).Freedom of speech. Initially intended as a defense of free speech but I came to the conclusion that every society needs to restrict freedom of speech, and that freedom of speech is mainly about power structures.Public Service (radio and TV) How Public Service is having a left-wing bias without being overtly left-wing.Feminism. Here I show its many fallacies and how it is connected with socialism.Anti-racism. Same as above.Social liberalism. How the left-wing and liberalism blended together. Looking into and countering arguments from such people as John Rawls and Thomas Piketty.The future.I printed 100 copies of which 70 are for sale (plus an e-book). It was self-published and cost around $1000 which included help with the design and typesetting and everything else to get it listed in bookstores, such as having an ISBN number. I don’t expect to sell many copies at all — in fact no one I sent the manuscript to for feedback even got back to me even if they initially said they would. Maybe they found it too hard to digest, maybe they disagreed with it, maybe they found it boring or maybe they found it badly written. I have no way of knowing, but with such little interest among those who got it for free I don’t expect hardly anyone to pay for it. I suspect that most right-wingers want to read a book that details how bad postmodernism is and how it is ruining society, and here I am making use of postmodernist terms. It might be too intellectual for most. In fact I don’t know who would want to read the book — it certainly won’t be the left-wingers or classical liberals, and I don’t have to credentials to interest the academics. Anyways, now I have a book published and they can’t take that away from me, unlike on social media where one can get cancelled and have their content removed any day without appeal. It was a mental strain but I wouldn’t say it was a struggle to fill the pages — in fact, I cut away some 100 000 words that will be discarded or appear in my next book.  It’s a nice feeling. My girlfriend is impressed that I was able to complete it. Writing a book like this is unlikely to make anyone wealthy, but I think the main advantage is that one learns so many new things. Writing on social media tends to become repetitive, as in “socialism is bad, look at Venezuela and Soviet”. Writing a book requires one to get involved in many new ideas and people I had never heard about, such as the German anti-liberal philosopher Carl Schmitt who has become one of the most quoted German thinkers and yet is surprisingly unknown among right-wingers. Or Lee Jussim, a social psychologist who for decades has shown how biased academia is. Will it get translated into English? Not by me, and I doubt anyone else would want to either. But maybe some day.

Here is one of the reviews of “The Newsmonger’s Apprentice”:   BOOK REVIEW: The Newsmonger’s Apprentice: The Life and Adventures of a Ghanaian Journalist By Alexander Shapiro From the author’s childhood in rural Northern Ghana through adolescence and young adulthood to his adult working life as a journalist for several decades, his eventual retirement from the Daily Graphic and his unexpected return to robust journalism, The Newsmonger’s Apprentice…The life and Adventures of a Ghanaian Journalist is a tightly-written and fast-paced autobiography narrated in lively, jumpy and delightful prose. George Sydney Abugri is best known as much for his award-grabbing journalism spanning several decades as for the sarcastic wit of his popular satirical column, “Letter to Jomo”, which ran in the Daily Graphic for more than two-and-a-half decades. The Newsmonger’s Apprentice is probably one of the most hilarious autobiographies ever written by an African journalist in recent decades, but it is also a story punctuated with sad narratives that could move you to tears and that threaten albeit unsuccessfully, to subvert the humour in this story of rare courage, perseverance and sheer tenacity of purpose. George Sydney Abugri was born Akudbila Abugri at the village of Zawse near Bawku in Ghana’s Upper East Region. “Everyone walked barefoot and clothes were sometimes washed without soap! Many young adults walked around with phalluses dangling between the thighs, like Adam taking a jog in Eden. Bare breasted women covered the nudity of the lower regions of the anatomy with primitive “thongs” fashioned from plant leaves”, the author recalls of his childhood. It was a childhood that also showed signs of an inquisitive mind as captured in a conversation with his Uncle Akudugu: “Uncle…” “Yes..?” “Is it true about the ghost? “What ghost” “The ghost which sits under the baobab tree. They say you fought the ghost” “Who told you?” “Apisiga and Awini” “Sure, I did” “Was the ghost a man or woman?” “A man.” “How do you know?” “He was a man” “Was he a white man?’ “No.” “They say all ghosts are white” “Pale, not white…” Having abandoned his teaching position in the naive hope of finding a job as a reporter once he arrived in Accra, Abugri was sorely disappointed to find on arrival in the capital, that finding a job as a reporter was easier said than done: “I woke early every morning and walked miles around Accra, combing newspaper houses looking for a job as a news reporter. People who travelled to Accra from the north of the country and happened to meet me whispered that I was crazy and I came close to believing it myself, for how could a professionally trained teacher suddenly abandon a fairly well-paying job and live like a tramp in the city, claiming to be hunting for a job as a reporter?” The author devotes a good part of the narrative to subsequent adventures in journalism and takes us through long as well as brief stops at The Rural Observer, The Palaver, The Echo, The Punch, the Daily Graphic and The General Telegraph. The author recounts how he was eventually recruited to work on the investigative weekly, The Punch, as its Northern Ghana correspondent. The author who subsequently moved to the Daily Graphic, also recalls the atmosphere at the Graphic on any given day in the early 1980s: “In the newsroom of the editorial department, hard-bitten editors and sub-editors of the old school took “wicked” pens to frightened reporters’ hand-written copies with merciless abandon and screamed at erring reporters who had problems getting beyond the lead paragraphs of stories and making any sense. Newsroom tension always peaked as bedtime for the next day’s issue approached, and the closer the time to the afternoon editorial conference, the louder and more menacing the screams, as everyone scurried frantically about like headless chickens trying to beat production deadlines. At any given time, some members of the editorial board tended to be sympathetic to the ruling political party and others to the political opposition. Each side tried to influence the selection of stories in such a way that projected the government and its appointees prominently and positively. There were often very heated arguments over the placement of stories. Physical confrontations at afternoon editorial conferences were not uncommon and occasionally, fists were let fly.” Some of the best chapters of the book include: “I stumble upon the Bone Setters”, “Up close with President Kwame Nkrumah”, “The arrest of Sidiki Diallo”, “Hobnobbing with Uncle Akudugu”, “A Monster Welcomes me to School”, “From Punch Weekly to the Daily Graphic”, “The Palaver and the Echo”, “Meeting President Rawlings”, “Coming to Cardiff University”, “A farewell to the Daily Graphic” and “Mr. X and the Telegraph newspaper.” The Newsmonger’s Apprentice is a great read.
